Award.AwardTitle: Student Team Support for International Challenge at American Society of Precision Annual Conference; Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania; October 28-November 1, 2019

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project supports 32 students studying at US institutions, including those from under-represented groups, to participate in the 34th Annual Meeting of the American Society for Precision Engineering (ASPE). The students will form teams that will participate in an international student challenge at ASPE. This funding will provide the students opportunities to exchange ideas with leading researchers and engineers from worldwide industrial and governmental facilities, as well as with students and faculty from both domestic and international schools. The students will also participate in expert tutorials.

This project will facilitate the formation of a cohort of students in the multidisciplinary field of precision engineering by their participation in an international student design competition and expert tutorials. Furthermore, this project will provide these students with the opportunity to learn the basic principles of precision engineering, how to prototype precision systems, and how to utilize enabling technologies like hardware programing and data acquisition and analysis. Participation in the 2019 ASPE Annual Meeting will give the students the opportunity to interact with leading experts from around the world, as well as with other students with similar interests.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Student Challenge was created to help The American Society of Precision Engineering to develop new talent that not only understands the basic precision engineering principles but also can use their hands to quickly build prototypes that demonstrate those principles.  

This award supported graduate and undergraduate students studying at US institutions to participate in the 34th and 35th Annual Meetings of the American Society for Precision Engineering (ASPE) in November 2019 and 2020 in Pittsburgh and Minnesota. Again, the award enables student teams to participate in an international student challenge and provides opportunities to exchange ideas with leading researchers and engineers from worldwide industrial and governmental facilities as well as with students and faculty from both domestic and international schools. The Annual Meeting of the American Society for Precision Engineering is considered a globally leading professional gathering in the precision engineering area; hence, the student participants learn the latest results and innovations in these fields. 

The challenge requires students to design build, test, and characterize a process to perform a specified task using only components supplied by the committee. The challenge for 2019 asked the teams to create a measuring instrument to measure mass using the Watt-balance principle. This was supported by NIST who provided traceable masses to test the team solutions. For the 2020 challenge student teams were required to make a machine for scribing optical diffraction grating rulings on a flat copper surface. Due to challenges presented by the pandemic, the conference became virtual and the challenge was changed to require teams to produce a scribe tool controller. Using the tool to make diffraction gratings is now the topic for the 2021 challenge.

Budget for this proposal was used to cover registration and tutorial expenses for student participants. Two students were also supported to attend the business meeting. Further funds were made available to cover travel and accommodation cost for Navajo Technical University and also purchase raw materials to manufacture equipment for equipment for the 2020 competition.

Benefits of the competition

The ASPE student challenge is a multi-disciplinary project that was designed to:

  • Challenge new talent that understands the basic PE engineering principles by requiring hands-on design and build of prototypes that demonstrate those principles.
  • Teach the importance of team collaboration, project management, troubleshooting and keep it simple.
  • Provide a setting for the students interact with peers from leading schools from around the world in precision engineering in an informal setting.
  • Provide a setting for the students interact with our aging world experts (most of the committee but this is now changing as previous participants are joining the committee) in an informal setting – important connections so they can follow up for advice.
  • Opportunity to have students see the benefits of working in precision engineering developing new devices.
  • Show students cases and ideas that operate at the limit of technological capability that do not have to be very expensive to experiment and build devices that are deterministic per design.
  • Give companies access to a larger pool of talent in the areas of precision engineering.
  • Give them the opportunity to work with a team with limited resources and time so they can value the importance of focusing on the important aspects of the project.
  • Encourage students to apply theory and use their own hands to quickly prototype devices.
  • Encourage students to learn many of the enabling technologies like hardware programing, data acquisition and analysis.
  • Having to construct apparatus by reusing subsystems and using a modular approach to solving multi-faceted tasks.
  • Non-precision schools, like Navajo Technical University, get access to non-traditional tools of precision engineering. Consequently, it provides an experiential exposure to methods and current technologies in this discipline.

Impact

Students were asked to self-identify ethnicity, race and gender by checking appropriate boxes in the registration form. Teams from Universities outside of the US were not supported by NSF and are therefore not included.  From this survey, computed from the total number of supported participants, an average diversity of 57% and 50% minority participation was recorded for the 2019 and 2020 conferences respectively. This exceeds the proposed target value of 40%.

Over the last five years eleven student participants have been employed by the sponsors and one team member is now a faculty member (NTU) and was the mentor to one of the 2020 teams. Universities that have participated include: University of Arizona at Tuscon, Texas A&M, UT Austin, UNC Charlotte, Chinese University of Hong Kong, MIT, University of Nottingham, UK, University of Michigan, North Carolina State University, Navajo Technical University. As onsite conferences resume, it is expected that more participants will become involved.
